Class FSMHandle

This is your direct link, or "handle," to a specific, live FSM (Finite State Machine) instance. üéÆ Think of it as the remote control for one particular character or object that's using an FSM.

graph TD A[FSMHandle (The Logic)] -->|Commands| B[IStateContext (The Data)]; B -->|Returns Data/Status| A;

object.ToString()
Namespace: TheSingularityWorkshop.FSM_API
Assembly: FSM_API.dll
Syntax
public class FSMHandle
Remarks

This handle is how you, as a game designer or system integrator, will typically interact with an FSM that's currently running. It allows you to:

  • Find out **what state** the FSM is currently in (CurrentState).
  • Tell the FSM to **change states immediately** (TransitionTo(string)).
  • And generally **manage** its life (like starting or stopping it).

It also gives you access to the FSM's IStateContext, which holds all the unique data for *this specific FSM instance*.

Tips for Using Your FSM Handle:

  • ‚úÖ **Safest Way:** Mostly, you'll just want to **check the FSM's CurrentState**. For example: `if (myCharacter.CurrentState == "Idle") { /* do something */ }`. This lets the FSM handle its own internal changes, which is generally best.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è **Advanced Use (Use with Care!):** You *can* directly access and change the Context (e.g., `myCharacter.Context.Health = 10;`). This is powerful, but it means you're stepping outside the FSM's own defined rules, so be careful not to break its intended behavior! Usually, context changes happen *inside* your FSM's state actions (OnEnter, OnUpdate, OnExit).

Constructors

| Edit this page View Source

FSMHandle(FSM, IStateContext, int)

Sets up a new FSM handle, linking it to an FSM blueprint and its specific data.

Declaration
public FSMHandle(FSM definition = null, IStateContext context = null, int id = -1)
Parameters
Type Name Description
FSM definition

The blueprint (FSM) for this FSM instance.
IStateContext context

The data bag (IStateContext) for this specific FSM instance.
int id

ID of the handle
Remarks

When you create an FSM handle:

  • It needs an `FSM` definition (the blueprint).
  • It needs a `context` (the data bag) specific to this running instance.
The FSM will immediately enter its InitialState as defined in its blueprint.
Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentNullException

This happens if you try to create an FSM handle without a blueprint (definition is null) or without a data bag (context is null).

Fields

| Edit this page View Source

Definition

This is the original blueprint (definition) of the FSM that this handle is controlling.

Declaration
public readonly FSM Definition
Field Value
Type Description
FSM
Remarks

It's like having the architectural plans for a house. You can look at them to understand the house's design (its states and transitions), but you can't change the house by drawing on these plans here. This is set when the FSM instance is first created.

Properties

| Edit this page View Source

Context

This is the data bag üéí (context) specific to this particular FSM instance.

Declaration
public IStateContext Context { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
IStateContext
Remarks

It holds all the changing information that your FSM's actions need to read from or write to (like a character's health, speed, or inventory). This "data bag" must follow the rules of the IStateContext interface.

You *can* directly change this context data here (e.g., `handle.Context.Score = 100;`). However, it's generally safer and clearer if these changes happen through the FSM's own `OnEnter`, `OnUpdate`, or `OnExit` actions for each state. Changing it directly from outside might bypass your FSM's carefully planned logic!

| Edit this page View Source

CurrentState

This tells you the current state name of this FSM instance.

Declaration
public string CurrentState { get; }
Property Value
Type Description
string
Remarks

For example, if your FSM is for a character, this might tell you "Idle," "Walking," or "Jumping." This is the best and safest way to check what your FSM is doing. This state name is updated automatically when the FSM moves between states.

Declaration

Type Description
bool
Remarks

It's considered true if its Context (data bag) is not empty and that context itself reports that it's valid.

Methods

| Edit this page View Source

EvaluateConditions()

Manually checks all the rules (conditions) for leaving the FSM's CurrentState.

Declaration
public void EvaluateConditions()
Remarks

This method is particularly useful if your FSM is set up to not automatically update (meaning its ProcessRate in the FSM blueprint is set to 0). In such cases, you would call EvaluateConditions() yourself whenever something happens that might cause a state change (like a player pressing a button, or an enemy seeing you).

If a transition's condition is met, the FSM will move to that new state. Only the *first* transition whose condition is true will be taken in a single evaluation.

| Edit this page View Source

ResetFSMInstance()

Resets this FSM instance back to its very first state (the InitialState) as defined in its blueprint. ‚Ü©Ô∏è

Declaration
public void ResetFSMInstance()
Remarks

This is like pressing a "restart" button for this specific FSM. It will:

  • Run the `OnExit` action of its current state.
  • Then run the `OnEnter` action of its initial state.
This is very useful for getting a complex FSM back to a known starting point.
| Edit this page View Source

TransitionTo(string)

Forces this FSM instance to immediately change to a specific state, ignoring any normal transition rules. üõë

Declaration
public void TransitionTo(string nextStateName)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string nextStateName

The name of the state you want the FSM to jump to.
Remarks

Use this when you need absolute control, like manually setting a character's state to "Dead" regardless of what they were doing.

When you force a transition, the FSM will:

  • Run the `OnExit` action of its current state.
  • Immediately run the `OnEnter` action of the nextStateName.
**Caution:** Bypassing normal FSM logic can sometimes lead to unexpected results if the target state isn't ready for a sudden jump.
Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

This happens if the nextStateName is empty, or if that state doesn't exist in your FSM's blueprint.
| Edit this page View Source

Update(string)

Tells this FSM instance to take one "step" or "tick" forward. üèÉ

Declaration
public void Update(string processGroup = "Update")
Parameters
Type Name Description
string processGroup

An optional name for the group this FSM belongs to, mainly used for error reporting. It defaults to "Update".
Remarks

During this step:

  • The `OnUpdate` action of its CurrentState will run.
  • It will then check if any transition rules are met to move to a new state.
If a transition rule is met, the FSM will exit its current state and enter the new one, and its CurrentState will be updated.

**IMPORTANT: Usually, you won't call this directly!** This method is typically called automatically by the FSM_API's internal system on a regular schedule (like every frame in a game). Only call this manually if you're building a very specific or custom update system for your FSMs. Calling it incorrectly can lead to unexpected behavior.
